title: Helper
text: don’t like pie charts, hard read. hard compare size slices slices display underlying data. However, someone asks make pie chart, simple wrapper function makes pie chart using ggplot2. ggpie function takes data frame fill argument specifies column use slices. next code shows example using penguins data set.
code: # ggpie is a wrapper around ggplot2 that makes it easy to make pie charts ggpie(penguins, fill = species)

title: Helper
text: Slope charts cool: show change variable time different groups. ggslope function wrapper around ggplot2 makes easy make slope charts. function takes data frame, times argument, outcome argument, group argument. next code shows example using data frame GDP income fake data two countries two time periods.
code: # toy data df <- tidyr::tribble(   ~times, ~country, ~gdp, ~inc,   "1990", "A", 22.3, TRUE,   "2000", "A", 44.6, TRUE,   "1990", "B", 12.3, FALSE,   "2000", "B", 4.6, FALSE )  # ggslope is a wrapper around ggplot2 ggslope(df,   times = times,   outcome = gdp,   group = country )

title: Apps
text: Linear Regression app simple app demonstrates use lm() function R. app allows pick different data sets run linear regression model. app shows different aspects linear regression models, interpretation coefficients, residuals, fitted values, error.

title: Apps
text: Titanic app simple app demonstrates use logistic regression R. app essentially Linear Regression app, uses logistic regression model instead lies focus interpretation logistic regression. app uses classic Titanic data set predicts survival passengers based different variables.

title: Apps
text: power analysis app illustrates statistical power ; depends sample size, effect size, significance level letting user adjust parameters fly. app uses pwr package calculate statistical power needed sample size depending user input. app shows picked parameters increase decrease statistical power (sample size, etc.) given chosen parameters.

title: Illustrations
text: Anscombe quartet set four datasets nearly identical simple descriptive statistics, yet appear different graphed. dataset consists eleven (x,y) points. constructed 1973 statistician Francis Anscombe demonstrate importance graphing data analyzing effect outliers statistical properties.

title: Illustrations
text: Boxplot Illustration shows main components boxplot. boxplot standardized way displaying distribution data based five-number summary: minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, maximum. can also show outliers.

title: Illustrations
text: Boxplot pitfalls shows main problem boxplots. boxplot shows distribution dataset, underlying data. jitter plot added show underlying data.

title: Illustrations
text: data format shows difference long wide data format. long format often preferred data analysis visualization. wide format often preferred data storage data entry.

title: Illustrations
text: plot shows different types joins inspired Data Wrangling dplyr tidyr chapter R Data Science book. plot shows different types joins: inner, left, right, full join.

title: Illustrations
text: datasaurus plot shows importance visualizing data. datasaurus plot shows summary statistics 12 datasets. plot shows importance visualizing data analyzing . datasaurus plot inspired Datasaurus Dozen paper.

title: Illustrations
text: Gapminder bubble chart shows life expectancy GDP per capita countries time. Gapminder bubble chart inspired Gapminder project.

title: Illustrations
text: Pac-Man plot shows many pie charts resemble Pac-Man.

title: Illustrations
text: Simpson’s paradox plot shows correlation two variables can change third variable added. underlines importance visualizing data causal inference, since overall may seem positive correlation, data split groups, correlation can negative.

title: Illustrations
text: students discriminated? UCB Admission plot shows admission rates different departments University California, Berkeley. UCB Admission case illustrates importance causal inference since seems women rejected, data split departments, opposite can true.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Edgar Treischl. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Treischl E (2024). edgar: personal package Edgar. R package version 0.0.1, https://github.com/edgar-treischl/edgar.
code: @Manual{,   title = {edgar: A personal package for Edgar},   author = {Edgar Treischl},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://github.com/edgar-treischl/edgar}, }

title: A personal package for Edgar
text: personal R package different stuff made R. installs source code illustrations, apps, functions wanted recycle (e.g., slope plots ggplot2). Feel free reuse code projects, course, can install package well.

title: A personal package for Edgar
text: can install package GitHub account: rest page provides example package’s content. can find examples articles.

title: A personal package for Edgar
text: created several shiny apps different purposes. example, power app illustrates statistical power depends sample size, effect size, significance level letting user adjust parameters fly.

title: A personal package for Edgar
text: Every now searched code specific graph wanted reuse. package includes graphs created might good starting point future self project. plotgraph() function runs installed source code returns graphs. example, know datasaurus plot?  Without input, plotgraph() function returns available graphs.
code: # plotgraph function runs the source code library(edgar) plot_graph("datasaurus.R") # list available graphs without input plot_graph() #> Error in plot_graph(): Please run `plotgraph()` with a valid argument. #> Valid examples are: #> anscombe_quartet.R #> boxplot_illustration.R #> boxplot_pitfalls.R #> data_joins.R #> datasaurus.R #> gapminder.R #> long_wide.R #> pacman.R #> simpson.R #> ucb_admission.R

title: A personal package for Edgar
text: package gives access helper functions make improve ggplot2 graphs. example, ggslope() returns slope plot may reuse provide necessary data. function wrapper geom_segment() geom_text() useful compare change variable time groups. following code shows use function.
code: library(tidyr) library(ggplot2)  #example data df <- tribble(  ~times, ~country,  ~gdp, ~inc,  "1990",   "A",  22.3, TRUE,  "2000",   "A",  44.6, TRUE,  "1990",   "B",  12.3, FALSE,  "2000",   "B",  4.6, FALSE  )  #slope plot ggslope(df,          times = times,         outcome = gdp,         group = country)+   theme_minimal()
